awd_titl_txt: Improving the STEM Higher Education Research Workforce: Examining Motivation as a Predictor of Faculty Research Development and Productivity
awd_abstract_narration:
Faculty research productivity in STEM disciplines drives scientific advancement, university-industry knowledge transfer, innovative economic activity, and data-driven government decision-making. In recent decades, however, USA STEM research productivity has plateaued despite increases in federal research funding, leading to questions of how to maximize productivity in the STEM academic research workforce beyond financial means. The objective of this project is to investigate the role of motivation in STEM higher education faculty research productivity and development. Motivated faculty are expected to be more productive and stay in the higher education workforce, particularly if they are from populations traditionally underrepresented in the STEM research workforce. Results of the current project will inform higher education institutions, particularly universities striving to increase scholarly productivity, as to specific strengths and deficits in STEM faculty motivation that relate to measurable gains in research productivity. This is a critical step toward designing research development interventions from university-based induction programs to NSF training grants aimed at bolstering motivation to enhance the productivity of STEM faculty researchers. Findings will provide guidance to universities on best practices and policies for supporting STEM faculty in producing innovative basic and applied scientific knowledge, tackling key social and economic challenges with their research, and training the next generation of flexible, knowledgeable, and diverse STEM researchers. This project is jointly funded by the Science of Science Innovation and Policy Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research. 

This multi-institution project will be the first to pair STEM faculty psychological surveys responses with bibliometric indicators of research productivity (publications, citations, social media attention). These data will be used to test a conceptual model hypothesizing how faculty characteristics (demographic, employment) and institutional qualities (research resources, social-environmental factors) relate to motivational variables (autonomy, competence, relatedness, interest, control, value, self-regulation, grit) that, if supported, should yield optimal intrinsic motivation and positive emotions, and result in enhanced research productivity (e.g., bibliometric, self-report). Structural equation modeling will be used to analyze the posited relationships cross-sectionally and predict the development of STEM faculty researchers longitudinally over a three-year period. Additionally, the project will examine hypothesized relationships among traditionally underrepresented groups in STEM fields based on gender, race, and ethnicity. This research will improve our understanding of the STEM higher education research workforce in several ways. First, this project represents the first interdisciplinary study pairing faculty survey data with independent, bibliometric indicators of research productivity. Second, these studies will utilize reliable and valid measures of variables relating to faculty research outcomes and evaluate the generalizability of the hypothesized model in a large USA sample of ~1,400 faculty across 10 higher education institutions. Third, this research will expand upon limited empirical findings investigating psychological variables associated with faculty research productivity and development, and explore the interplay with faculty characteristics (e.g., underrepresented minority groups in STEM) and institutional qualities. Fourth, the project will utilize established motivation theories rarely applied to faculty research productivity and development to generate new knowledge and best practices in this under-examined domain. As such, the current project will guide the establishment of critical variables and benchmarks for STEM faculty motivation to predict research productivity and development over time. This project is jointly funded by the Science of Science Innovation and Policy Program and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Robert Stupnisky (PI), Vincent Lariviere, and Nathan Hall (co-PIs) completed the research project, "Improving the STEM Higher Education Research Workforce: Examining Motivation as a Predictor of Faculty Research Development and Productivity" supported by the NSF. The major goal of this three-year project was to investigate the role of motivation in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) higher education faculty research productivity and development. The study paired STEM faculty psychological surveys responses (annual, spring) from ten USA Doctoral institutions (R2 Higher Research Activity Carnegie Classification) with bibliometric indicators of research productivity (e.g., publications, citations). During Year 2 the researchers also collected qualitative data using focus groups and individual interviews.

The Year 1 data (2020, N = 727) yielded several key results, including that the research motivation scales showed excellent reliability and validity based on Cronbach's alpha and confirmatory factor analyses. Furthermore, STEM faculty basic psychological needs of autonomy and competence were significant predictors of autonomous motivation (research engagement for enjoyment or perceived importance), which in turn significantly predicted self-reported research success beyond demographic, position details, and social-environmental factors. Other studies with this data focused on the unique experiences of under-represented minority faculty, mental health, mentorship, and research teams.

The Year 2 data (2021, N = 741) aimed to test the Research Emotions Questionnaire among STEM faculty and found it to be valid and reliable. Structural equation model results showed perceived control and value appraisals significantly predicted research emotions and in turn success. Women reported more anxiety and disappointment, under-represented minorities reported more anxiety, international faculty consistently reported more positive and less negative research emotions than domestic professors, and finally full professors reported more enjoyment and pride, as well as the least anxiety and disappointment, compared to their more junior colleagues. Other studies utilizing this data examined the impact of COVID-19 on faculty motivation, grit, as well as gender and racial microaggressions against URM faculty.

Year 3 (2022, N = 580) assessed faculty beliefs that their research motivation can improve, their intentions to change, perceptions of typical interventions, and how their current motivation and success relates to change intentions. Indeed, many faculty believed their research motivation and productivity can improve and are working to do so (38%) - typically faculty who are autonomous motivated and successful already. Alternatively, many faculty reported room for improvement but are not making attempts at change (16%) - some poorly motivated and unsuccessful, and others were highly successful. Other studies utilizing this data examined faculty self-reported ADHD symptoms, stress, and research self-efficacy. Finally, all three datasets were merged for future research projects examining faculty motivation and research success over time.

Findings will provide guidance to universities on policies for best supporting STEM research faculty to produce innovative basic and applied scientific knowledge, to tackle key social and economic challenges with their research, and to train the next generation of flexible, knowledgeable, and diverse STEM researchers. Our project's findings potentially can be used to develop support services that can act to increase the STEM labor force by focusing on the recruitment and retention of high-quality individuals, particularly women and underrepresented minorities in STEM. Such recruitment and retention could help to increase our nation's ability to utilize the talents of all its citizens regardless of gender and race/ethnicity and in turn, make our nation stronger on the global market.
